titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Francis Griffith Newlands Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane E. Kaplan, William E. Brown, Jr., and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:11

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers contain correspondence, speeches, reports, scrapbooks, and other material documenting the political career of Francis G. Newlands. The papers highlight Nevada Democratic and Silver Party politics and focus on Newlands's legislative programs on transportation, particularly railroads and inland waterways, interstate commerce, irrigation, flood control, land reclamation, currency and silver, conservation and forests, and tariffs. An addition to the collection contains over 600 personal letters to and from the Newlands family members, financial files, photographs, and topical files.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Francis Griffith Newlands Papers (MS 371). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Scrapbooks, 1887-1918, are available on microfilm HM 132.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Edith Newlands Johnston, ca. 1932. Purchased from Barney Chapman, 2008 (Accession 2009-M-028).

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Scrapbooks, 1887-1918 are available on microfilm (13,270 frames on 15 reels, 35mm.) from Scholarly Resources, Inc., Wilmington, Delaware.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series and one addition: I. Correspondence and Papers, 1869-1917. II. Topical Files, 1869-1936. III. Scrapbooks, 1887-1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Francis Griffith Newlands Papers are composed of correspondence, speeches, reports, scrapbooks, and printed material which document the political career of Francis G. Newlands. The papers highlight Nevada Silver and Democratic Party politics and focus on Newlands's legislative programs on transportation, particularly railroads and inland waterways, interstate commerce, irrigation, flood control, land reclamation, currency and silver, conservation and forests, and tariffs. An addition to the collection contains over 600 personal letters to and from the Newlands family members, financial files, photographs, and topical files.

In addition, the papers contain more than fifty scrapbook volumes of mounted clippings from 1887 to 1918. The scrapbooks, which contain the most complete and extensive record of Newlands's election campaigns and legislative programs, are arranged by topic and concern: Nevada politics, the Newlands Reclamation Act of 1902, railway legislation, irrigation, inland waterways, flood control, the Interstate Trade Commission, foreign affairs, the tariff, race problems, labor legislation, and the death of Senator Newlands. The scrapbooks were reproduced on fifteen reels of microfilm (HM 132) in 1982 after which the original volumes were discarded.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Francis Griffith Newlands was born on August 28, 1848, in Natchez, Mississippi. He attended Yale College from 1867-1869, and graduated from Columbian College (George Washington University) in 1869. He received an honorary degree (M.A.) in 1901. He moved to San Francisco and practiced law in California (1870-1888). Newlands moved to Nevada in 1888 and won election to the House of Representatives (1893-1903). He subsequently served Nevada as U.S. Senator (1903-1917). Newlands died on December 24, 1917.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, CORRESPONDENCE, consists of fifty-six boxes of Newlands's incoming and outgoing letters. The correspondence is arranged in chronological order. An alphabetical list of correspondents is appended at the end of this register, and correspondence to or from individuals named on this list may be located by consulting the Manuscripts and Archives Departmental catalog.

Though the earlist items in the series date from 1869 the bulk of the correspondence dates after Newlands's election the Senate in 1902. Correspondents include constituents, other Nevada politicians, elected representatives from other states, members of the Democratic Party hierarchy, and leaders of several national organizations concerned with issues such as the improvement of inland waterways, flood control, irrigation and transportation. Newlands's interest in the preservation of the beauty of Washington, D.C. is discussed in correspondence with several prominent architects. The volume of correspondence increases steadily and in proportion to Newlands's seniority and prominence in national politics. The most voluminous correspondence dates from 1913 and 1914 following the election of Democratic President Woodrow Wilson.

The earliest correspondence contains occasional references to Newlands's legal career in San Francisco, his concerns over investments as trustee of his father-in-law's estate, and his interests in the development of the Washington, D.C. suburb of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Correspondence from Newlands's career in the U.S. House of Representatives is sparse and mainly concerns the interests of constituents in military appointments, pensions, or post office matters.

Beginning in 1902 the correspondence contains more substantive exchanges on Nevada fusion party politics and the alignment of Nevada Democrats with Silver Party interests. Major correspondents at this time include William E. Sharon, and Nathan W.Roff, chairman and secretary, respectively, of the Silver Party State Central Committee; John H. Dennis of the Reno Journal; Clarence Van Duzen, Newlands's private secretary who became Congressman from Nevada when Newlands was elected to the Senate; Ernest L. Bingham, editor of the Nevada State Journal; H. F. Bartine; and John Sparks, the governor of Nevada. Later Nevada political matters are discussed in correspondence with Frank Reber, managing editor of the Reno Gold Circle News; James T. Boyd, a Nevada state senator; and George A. Bartlett, who succeeded Van Duzen as representative at large in 1908. Some of Newlands's interest in irrigation is reflected in correspondence with William Franklin Herrin, general attorney of the Southern Pacific Company, but there is surprisingly little documentation on the important 1902 Newlands's Reclamation Act.

Newlands's continuing interests in the problems of inland waterways led to his appointment to the Inland Waterways Commission in 1907. There is correspondence with Gifford Pinchot on this work. There are also exchanges with Millard F. Hudson, Newlands's clerk or secretary, during Newlands's cruise down the Mississippi with the commission. As is generally the case during Newlands's periodic absences from Washington the correspondence with office staff members is detailed and reveals Newlands's thoughts and concerns. Letters from staff members picture the workings of the office.

By 1909 the proportion of constituent correspondence decreases noticeably, and there are a greater number of exchanges with representatives of national lobbying organizations and federal bureaus and commissions. Some of these involve Newlands's position as a vice-president of the National Rivers and Harbors Congress and work with Louisiana Senator and Congress president Joseph Eugene Ransdell, while correspondence with James Finch Callbreath concerns the American Mining Congress. The most frequent exchanges concern the National Irrigation Association which became the National Reclamation Association. With its program for the "advancement of forestry, irrigation, drainage, flood prevention, and river regulation", and for "expansion of interal trade and the creation of larger home markets" the association most closely represented Newlands's own interests, and its director George H. Maxwell was an inveterate campaigner with Newlands. Other association correspondents include: Edmund T. Perkins of the National Drainage Congress and the American Reclamation Federation; Thomas R. Shipp, executive secretary of the National Conservation Congress; and Arthur Hooker, secretary of the National Irrigation Congress. Federal officials of importance to Newlands's various legislative programs include Frederick Haynes Newell, director of the U.S. Reclamation Service, Fred Dennett, commissioner of the General Land Office; George Otis Smith, director of the U.S. Geological Survey; and Herbert Knox Smith and Joseph E. Davies, both commissioners of the Bureau of Corporations. There are relatively few exchanges with Republican Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft.

The 1912 correspondence reflects Newlands's participation in the Democrative presidential campaign, and there are exchanges with Franklin K.Lane, William Gibbs McAdoo, Josephus Daniels, and Woodrow Wilson. Some of the correspondence in June 1912 concenns Newlands's attempt to introduce a Negro disfranchisement plank into the Democratic platform. Letters discussing Newlands's involvement in an investigation of the Titanic disaster are also present in 1912 files. Nevada politics is again a concern following the death of Senator George S. Nixon, and there is correspondence concerning Key Pittman, the Nevada Democrat elected to the Senate in 1912.

The voluminous 1913 and 1914 correspondence files contain many letters concerning tariff issues. Constituents, such as George Wingfield, write frequently expressing views on the protection of wool, sugar beets, meats, and other Western products and on Panama Canal tolls. In April 1913 there is extremely heavy correspondence relating to Newlands's bill for the creation of a Board of River Regulation. Newlands's bill creating an Interstate Trade Commission is the subject of many exchanges in 1914. There are also several discussions of Newlands's support for women's suffrage in exchanges with Anne H. Martin, president of the Nevada Equal Franchise Society.

There is a marked decrease in the correspondence from 1915 until Newlands's death in 1917. Some correspondence concerns the Interstate Commerce Commission, and there are also exchanges with architect Cass Gilbert and others attempting to prevent the erection of a central power plant in Washington, D.C. Correspondence with James D. Finch, Newlands's secretary at the time, concerns Nevada election campaigning for Wilson, but there is relatively little correspondence concerning the National Democratic Party, its 1916 convention, or platform. Newlands's concerns about labor and the railroads during World War I are not discussed in any substantive way in the series.
At the end of the series there are three letterbooks containing copies of Newlands's outgoing public letters for the period 1899-1905, some signed by Newlands's clerk at the time, Harvey M. Friend.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES II, TOPICAL FILES, includes material filed by subject which reflects Newlands's interests in various programs and pieces of legislation. Files may contain Newlands's views as expressed in speeches, Senate hearings and testimony, articles, drafts of legislation, and notes. The files also include background material such as minutes, reports, U.S. Government Printing Office publications, copies of bills, speeches and writings of others, issues of professional journals and popular periodicals, clippings, maps, charts, and photographs.

Many of Newlands's campaign speeches are filed in the section Political Issues along with delegate lists, platforms, endorsements, posters, and other campaign memorabilia. Other campaign material is found in folders 711-712. The section Speeches is composed of a paste-up of a publication "Remarks of the Honorable Francis G. Newlands" which includes Newlands's speeches in Congress. Waterways is the largest section, but there are also substantive files under Foreign relations, Interstate Trade Commission, Irrigation, and Railroads. Files under Miscellanea relate to some of Newlands's less well documented concerns such as the Washington, D.C. central power plant issue and its zoo; the development of Chevy Chase, Maryland; and the Titanic disaster.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains files arranged alphabetically by topic. Material for each topic is arranged alphabetically by record type and/or topic. Miscellanea is arranged at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The scrapbooks in this series contain information on many topics with which Newlands was associated during his life. The original scrapbooks were microfilmed for preservation purposes, and then discarded. Patrons must use microfilm HM 132.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this accession comprises over 600 personal letters to and from the Newlands family members, including members of the Charles Johnston family, Washington, D.C. (Two daughters of Francis Newlands married two sons of the Johnston family.) Financial files, photographs, and topical files are included, listed alphabetically by topic, and chronologically by year therein.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letter to Edythe Newlands from Lyman Gage, written during his term as U. S. Secretary of the Treasury.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to Edythe Newlands containing an invitation to ceremony and Citizens Guard ribbon. (President McKinley signed the "Newlands Resolution," named after Senator Francis Newlands, on July 7, 1898, to officially annex Hawaii to the United States.)
